awd_titl_txt: Suburban Social Contacts and Changing Demographic Balances
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States is becoming an increasingly multi-ethnic society.  This demographic reconfiguration is expected to have widespread impacts. The research supported by this award will investigate one of these impacts:  how the increasing residential proximity of different ethnic groups living in the same neighborhoods affects their social interactions. Investigating this question is complicated by another well-established social trend: decreasing interactions within and between all social groups, not just across ethnic lines.  Therefore, the overarching research question is, "What does the increase in racial and ethnic diversity in national residential patterns mean as residential social ties among all neighbors, not only across race or ethnicity, become weaker?" The research is important because neighborhood social cohesion affects both community security and quality of life. Findings from this research will help social scientists, policy makers, and city planners to better understand what supports healthy neighborhoods during periods of widespread social change.

The research will be carried out in a suburban community near Chicago. The researcher chose this site because it is an established, mixed Latino and non-Latino,  middle-class neighborhood, where similarities of class and experience could be expected to facilitate inter-ethnic contacts, if other factors,  such as ethnic sorting and decreasing sociality, were not also at work. Data will be collected through a combination of social science methods, including household surveys of a stratified sample of 128 households, 64 structured interviews, archival research, and on-going participant observation. The surveys and interviews will be applied to an equal number of Latino and non-Latino households. Two adult respondents will be surveyed and interviewed in every household whenever possible with the aim to also detect gender-related variations. Findings from the research will contribute to remaking overly monolithic analytical categories such as class, race, and ethnicity. The research also will contribute to improving the quality of life in America's neighborhoods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Until the late 1980’s suburban residential areas were overwhelming middle to upper-middle-class white concentrations. In the last four decades, poverty and residents of color have become increasingly present in many suburbs.

A key finding of the funded project concerns the relationship of the two trends: suburban poverty growth and more residents of color. The finding is that the two trends are different although tied together in broader developments. Their relationships involve wider processes and important distinctions. The broader relation of the two growths is mostly quantitative. It concerns the increasing percentages of people of color in the country’s total population. As the percentage of non-whites increases, there is more potential for becoming more present in settings that were overwhelmingly white.

This demographic residential dispersion relates also to a qualitative change, the economic polarization process most groups in the country have experienced since the 1980s. It relates to upward mobility advances some people of color have made as beneficiaries in the polarization, which lead to their relocation to affluent neighborhoods or the suburbs. However, it also relates to downward mobility of many who have been inversely affected by the same development. For example, the growths of people of color as well as poor people in suburbs are directly connected to gentrification.  Public and private investments in urban centers attract or retain well-off residents but displaces poor or less affluent residents. Some of them move or were moved to the suburbs. In summary, suburban poverty increases are not only due to poor people of color moving to suburbs:  poor as well as upwardly mobile people of color moved to the suburbs along with other poor and upwardly mobile white and other residents.

My research proposal sprang from my observation that not some Latino residents in the suburb were well off. I then noticed similarities in U.S. Census data on income, English proficiency, U.S. socialization, and family compositions. Based on those similarities, I proposed to explore the “remaking of the Middle class” claim made in a very influential book written by Richard Alva and Victor Nee, based merely on statistical data. As I foresaw, the claim is faulty to the point of being dangerously misleading. My fieldwork shows that to begin with, and as stated above, not all increases of minorities in suburbs involved upwardly mobile residents. Likewise, the “residential assimilation” they rashly proclaimed, based on mere physical proximity, oversimplifies dramatically the persistent—even widening--social distance that prevails despite contiguity. My sustained follow-up of data and fieldwork observations, moreover, reveal that the income levels of Latinos exhibit shifting and discrepant trajectories, which undermines the celebratory claim of the “remaking” of the mainstream.

Declining income levels for Latinos are also complicated by contrasting local trends for African and Asian American residents. The contrasting trends. it could be argued, give some validity to the “remaking” of the mainstream claim. Yet, why are they happening, at least in terms of African Americans, later than the incipient and shaky Latino trends? Above all, the over-optimistic claim fails the test of time also in terms of broader scopes, such as the political divisions impacting all social—not only racial—interactions.

In terms of broader impacts, the most relevant outcome of my fieldwork is the illustration of a complex local context of the ongoing transition to a society in which the number of whites declines. Highlighting everyday dynamics of institutional arrangements, such as the blind bureaucratic implementation of the inequity fostering “Career and College Program” by the school district, my findings underscore the lack of involvement of citizens, cocooned in the overwhelm and dormancy of suburban living. The atomistic arrangement, which may no longer only be experienced in suburbs, fosters the social disruptions of worsening economic polarization and political radicalism, for some, and apathy or immobility over public matters, for most.

In academic terms, the central outcome is the attempt to redirect the “counting” of population groups towards a focus on “accounting”—in the various senses of the term. It is not only the numerical grouping of “whites” or “people of color” that matters. The crucial question, my research reveals, concerns qualifying purposes: why and how is it that the transition to a “minority”/ “majority” society matters? What are the racializing impulses and outcomes underlining the question?  More abstractly, what does difference account for, and by what criteria is difference to be ascertained?

 Paradoxically, my research may not answer directly my proposal’s central question: "What does the increase in racial and ethnic diversity in national residential patterns mean as residential social ties among all neighbors, not only across race or ethnicity, become weaker?" The seeming paradox is a returned emphasis on the centrality of social cohesion in all that is human.
